The timing of these authorized "leaks" are so transparent; and maybe that's what Obama was talking about when he ran on government transparency.

OK. So Obama, in his desperation to mollify the increasingly outraged public while avoiding any actual debate or reform, has managed to find one instance where one of the hand-picked right-wing groupthinking kangaroos on the FISA court hesitated in his appointed duty to quickly rubber-stamp an NSA request. That authorized "leak" of a classified ruling was presumably part of his stated effort to make the public "comfortable" with limitless NSA surveillance, by showing that the FISA Court is at least occasionally capable of entertaining questions about systemic violations of the privacy of American citizens.

I don't know how many people who worry about the surveillance dragnet are now "comfortable." But the release of this ruling only makes me more uncomfortable, and gives me more reason to distrust anything Obama or Clapper tell us. It hints at the surveillance of Americans being far more extensive than Snowden's disclosures (so far) have suggested. And also that the FISA Court would be powerless to do anything about unlawful surveillance of Americans even if they were inclined to do so. (And, of course, the court is specifically designed to facilitate and legitimize the expansion of the surveillance dragnet rather than to provide any real oversight.)

All this ruling really shows is that it's time to have the debate that Obama pretends to want, but is actually trying to prevent at all costs.

The biggest stumbling block to real mitigation is not scientific uncertainty.  It is lack of public conviction that climate change makes a real difference that warrants the effort and sacrifice that will be necessary to effectively mitigate it.  When it comes to getting the public to accept that this problem really matters to each of us (enough for example that people consider climate when voting), there is probably no better strategy than to engage people in thinking about here and now events, and wherever possible get people to take small actions.  Taking action, even if not directly effective mitigation, is likely to move people psychologically into thinking of climate problems as their problems.

The horse is already out of the barn. It was apparent all the way back in the eighties that American culture was such that the new economy wouldn't be able to use all the poorly educated and unmotivated people America was producing.

Now that the horse is out of the barn, to use another barnyard parable, the chickens are coming home to roost. Our problem is a culture that for too many isn't ever going to work. Fast food, tv, and entitlements. Where is the education and skill acquisition? Morbidly obese Americans wonder what went wrong. Well, for starters, we stopped thinking and supposed that we were just entitled to do well. So much for that.

It's taken thirty years to turn much of America into mush and it will take thirty years to fix it, if we have the will.

It is true that profit percentages have rarely been higher. But that is just another symptom of the uselessness of too many American workers. Keep buying those hamburgers and loading up at Wal-Mart. Don't pay much attention to skills and here we are. Liberals think it is a conservative conspiracy which government can fix. Conservatives think it is just rewards for capital.

The truth: Our fault for permitting our culture to become irrelevant to the challenges we face. That is a mistake our competitors don't seem to be making. We have natural advantages, energy, bi-coastal maritime access, cheap river transportation systems from the heartland to world markets, largest arable land in the world, etc., but we waste them.

Last night I viewed David Attenborough's film of Birds of Paradise in New Guinea. I am not a scientist but I am also not a conservative, having voted for Obama twice.  However, I remain skeptical of being asked to accept evolution as the only explanation of the complexity around us. Ironically, I assume it is because of the advance of science that we are able to see more complexity, for example inside the uterus, inside the eye, the brain. Prof. Nagel argues that "...since the long process of biological evolution is responsible for the existence of conscious organisms, and since a purely physical process cannot explain their existence, it follows that biological evolution must be more than just a physical process, and the theory of evolution, if it is to explain the existence of conscious life, must become more than just a physical theory."

Nagel hinges his argument on the fact that science has not yet explained everything. Perhaps Prof. Nagel should consider the fact that what we do not know is an ever decreasing proportion of all that can be known. He might consider that we may very well explain consciousness in the not too distant future.

There is no doubt that electronic surveillance is a necessary tool in a dangerous world, but the NSA unwisely seems to have decided on its own that it will collect any and all information it can gather, never mind that it would be impossible to analyse most of it. Hence, US citizens’ e-mail and telephone calls were collected and saved even though this information had no relevance to national security.

The more explanations that are given by the NSA and the Obama administration, the more one thinks that that this collection was not accidental, but instead very deliberate. And contrary to the administration’s contention, Snowden will historically be remembered as a whistleblower and not a traitor. In fact, for the first time since he took office the President’s explanation regarding the NSA activities stretches the bounds of credibility.

It is a pity that a program that is absolutely necessary at this time in our history was abused by over-zealous interlopers who couldn’t resist doing the wrong thing just because they could.

Let's see, secret government activity monitored by secret court that issues secret rulings that the secret government activities are unconstitutional. And what protection of our Constitutional rights is that? We don't even know about the secret ruling until years later when the government decided to let us know about it (which it did not have to do and probably never would have if not for Snowden). The unconstitutional secret government activity could nevertheless continue if the government wanted to because the secret court's rulings are secret and there is no enforcement mechanism for its rulings anyway.

I feel so safe and protected by Obama and every leading Democrat and Republican member of Congress who continue to defend this secret government activity! It is a comfort to know that now matter what party is in office or who is elected this secret government activity will continue.

It is curious that those Democrat partisans who oppose this secret spying on all of us word their complaints on these pages as criticism of Bush/Cheney and Republicans generally. Whereas Republican partisans who oppose this secret spying word their complaints here as criticism of Obama and Democrats generally. When will they learn that all the leading politicians of both parties are our enemies. They should read and learn the lessons taught by that greatest liberal/conservative of all, Democrat Thomas Jefferson.

To me, this is evidence that oversight is taken quite seriously as is the duty to follow the rules for gathering intelligence. I am reassured but that does not mean that we do not need work on oversight.
For example, we need to hear something about how police know to set up a person interested in bomb making. We have heard that sting operations have caught persons interested in building bombs. That's fine but, were anyone's rights violated? Is there a place for those intending to commit a crime to be caught based on email content? Shouldn't we have some clarity on that?

As a former Obama enthusiast, I sincerely hope for the good of the country that Snowden's leaks sink this presidency. The lesson for future presidents that Americans will not tolerate this is far more important than anything Obama might achieve in the next year and a half.
